description.narrative: Demonstrable and sustainable increase in compliance with relevant international human rights standards, in particular the UN Standard Minimum Rules for the Treatment of Prisoners, in the Kenyan correctional system as a whole, and a selection of pilot penal institutions in particular, including through more human rights responsive and coordinated approaches reform initiatives in the administration of justice in Kenya.

Raoul Wallenberg- Institutet i Lund (RWI) har ansökt till Sida om 34 miljoner kronor i stöd för genomförandet av andra fasen av deras Kenya-program inom kriminalvården, perioden 2015-2019. RWI är ett fristående akademiskt institut knutet till Lunds universitet och har kontor i flera utvecklingsländer, bla i Nairobi, Kenya. Sida har mångårig erfarenhet från samarbete med RWI och har också tecknat ett ramavtal med institutet, vilket harmoniserar och reglerar de allmänna villkor som ska gälla i samarbetet.
Insatsens övergripande mål är att stärka Kenyas kriminalvårsmyndigheter inkl. frivården (Kenya Prisons Service, KPS och Kenya Probation and Aftercare Services, KPAS) samt domstolsväsendet så att deras verksamhet överensstämmer med det internationella mänskliga rättighetsramverket, särskilt de standards som finns för behandling av intagna (UN Standard Minimum Rules for the Treatment of Prisoners, SMR). Den nuvarande situationen inom kriminalvården i Kenya är prekär, med överfulla fängelser, bristande, och inte sällan brutal behandling av fångar, särskilt svåra förhållande för svagare grupper som funktionsnedsatta, ungdomar m fl, avsaknad av särskilda åtgärder för kvinnliga fångar mm. RWI kommer att genom i huvudsak utbildning i praktisk tillämpning av MR-ramverk, reformering av myndigheternas internutbildning, bidrag till byggande av MR-institutioner inom myndigheterna och bidrag till ändring i lagstiftning försöka nå insatsmålet. Programmet passar också väl in i det totala svenska stödet till rättssektorn i Kenya som förutom fängelsereform också reformering av rättsväsendet. Programmets totala budget är 34 miljoner kronor över fem år. RWI söker inte medel från någon annan biståndsgivare. Detta beslut täcker de två sista åren 2018-2019 av den andra fasen.

Sida has supported the first phase and the first part of the second phase of this programme. Sida assesses the program as highly relevant and that the engagement so far has yielded good results. A mid-term review was conducted in November 2017 which confirmed the good results and recommended the program to continue. Some calibrations have been made to the original proposal -i.e Component 2 of the programme has been more clearly defined and RWI will work more strategically for enhancing effective use of non-custodial measures in Kenya. The overall objective of the programme remains the same: to enhance compliance with international human rights standards in the management of Kenya´s correctional system, including through supporting more human rights responsive and coordinated approaches to the administration of justice in Kenya. It is proposed that an amount of 16 million SEK will be set aside during the period 1 January 2018 - 31 December 2019 for continue funding this programme.

description.narrative: 140 officers (49 women) had undergone Human Rights Officer (HRO) training. Not all are currently deployed as intended under the Terms of Reference for HROs, although data supplied by the Human Rights Office indicates that a great many are using the desired abilities and approaches. For example, although comprehensive data on the amount of human rights training provided by HROs is not available, a study conducted by the Human Rights Office found that between June and December 2017 over 49 oneweek trainings were carried out, reaching more than 1,200 KPS staff members. 148 Officers in Charge (OIC)s and other senior officers (50 women) had undergone human rights and leadership training, although it is difficult to assess the extent to which each individual is using the desired abilities and approaches. Reporting on social media has shown that many are carrying out human rights action plans, while repeat audits at the four KPS-RWI pilot prisons also found ongoing improvement in compliance since 2015 – these prisons intended to "take the temperature" of the system as a whole. A number of internal accountability mechanisms have been established within KPS, most notably the Department Human Rights Committee (DHRC), a national-level body charged with overseeing initiatives towards compliance with international standards. The DHRC has issued and followed up a number of human rights policy directives, which include a directive specifically outlining approaches to accountability. The directives have been drafted by HROs with advice from RWI, and followed them up by inter alia organising independent human rights audits without RWI assistance. There has further been close attention paid by the DHRC to the needs of women, children and other vulnerable and marginalised groups, which are specifically addressed within policy directives such as those relating to family contact, searches and medical examinations. Follow-up audits at the four KPS-RWI pilot prisons found increases in compliance in most of the identified areas, with the general observation that less progress has been observed in relation to classification, basic necessities and work. The most notable progress has been observed at a female institution (Shimo La Tewa Women). Future follow-up audits will help determine whether such reforms have spread to the DHRC model prisons, while ongoing review is needed to determine whether the ACP initiative will have a lasting impact in terms of the many human rights standards dependent on risk- and needs-based decision making. Drafts of new Prisons and Young Offender Institution Acts have been developed under the Programme, incorporating relevant international standards including those for vulnerable groups, although the legislation has yet to be passed. A range of policy directives have been issued by the DHRC, incorporating also the needs of vulnerable groups, while progress has been made towards other policies such as on rights-based prisoner employment.
